Expectation1: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation1: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Situation2: They prepare a sermon for Sunday service to guide the congregation in moral decisions.
Story: As I stood before the jury, my gavel poised, I felt the weight of my responsibility as a judge. My instructions were clear, rooted in the precedent I had studied just last night. Suddenly, my clerk slipped me a note—an urgent Supreme Court ruling had just overturned the very precedent I was relying on. My mind raced. I was expected to stay current, to uphold the law with precision, but I was also scheduled to deliver a sermon in two days, guiding my congregation through the complexities of moral decision-making. The words I had prepared for Sunday echoed in my mind: “We must stand firm in our principles, even when the world shifts beneath our feet.” Yet here I was, the world shifting, and I was expected to adapt instantly. The courtroom watched me, waiting for clarity. My congregation would soon look to me for certainty. I felt torn, the demands of law and faith pulling me in opposite directions, each expecting unwavering guidance. My heart pounded as I wrestled with which voice to heed first.
